author: Josh Stewart
title: Kurt Busch's NASCAR highs and lows | Newsday

organizations.name: roush racing irwin industrial tools ford

text:
(Credit: Getty Images / Sean Gardner) 
Kurt Busch celebrates after winning the Daytona 500 on February 26, 2017 in Daytona Beach, Florida. Kurt Busch's NASCAR highs and lows Updated February 26, 2017 7:39 PM By JOSH STEWART Advertise here Kurt Busch, the 2004 NASCAR Cup champion, won his first Daytona 500 on Feb. 26, 2017. It was by far his biggest victory since 2015, when he was suspended to start the season based on domestic violence claims levied by former girlfriend Patricia Driscoll. He denied the accusation and even said Driscoll is a trained assassin. A family court decision in Delaware that ruled a domestic violence event occurred prompted the suspension, but a subsequent attorney general's office decision not to pursue criminal charges against Busch helped pave the way for the driver's return. This is par for the course for Busch, whose career has been a mixed bag of celebrations and setbacks. Kurt Busch's NASCAR highs and lows (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 97 Ford, fights for position with Ricky Rudd during a Daytona 500 qualifying race at Daytona International Speedway in Daytona Beach, Florida, on Feb. 15, 2001. Busch famously drew Dale Earnhardt Sr.'s ire during the rookie driver's inaugural Daytona 500. Earnhardt, who was killed in a last-lap crash, delivered a middle finger Busch's way earlier in the race. (Credit: AP) 
Kurt Busch shows his displeasure with fellow driver Jimmy Spencer, No. 41, after crashing in the third turn during the ninth running of the Brickyard 400 at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway on Sunday, Aug. 4, 2002. Busch thought Spencer forced him into the third turn wall. (Credit: AP) 
Jimmy Spencer walks away from his car during practice for the Southern 500 on Friday, Aug. 29, 2003, at Darlington Raceway in Darlington, South Carolina. Spencer was back at the racetrack after a one-week suspension he received for punching Kurt Busch in the face at Michigan International Speedway, just one stanza in their long feud. 
ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISE HERE (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 97 Roush Racing Sharpie Ford, sprays his team members with champagne after winning the NASCAR Nextel Cup Series Championship at the Ford 400 on Nov. 21, 2004, at the Homestead Miami Speedway in Homestead, Florida. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, the 2004 NASCAR NEXTEL Cup champion, poses with the Cup in Manhattan's Times Square on Dec. 2, 2004. (Credit: Getty Images) 
NASCAR NEXTEL Cup Series Champion for 2004 Kurt Busch and then-girlfriend Eva Bryan pose with the championship trophy before the awards banquet at the Waldorf Astoria on Dec. 3, 2004, in Manhattan. The couple married in 2006, but divorced in 2011. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kenny Wallace stands next to the No. 97 Roush Racing IRWIN Industrial Tools Ford before the NASCAR Nextel Cup Series Checker Auto Parts 500 at Phoenix International Raceway on Nov. 13, 2005, in Avondale, Arizona. Wallace was a last-minute replacement for Kurt Busch, who was fired on race day after being cited the day before for criminal reckless driving. Busch had already signed to join Penske Racing the following year. (Credit: AP/Jae C. Hong) 
Kurt Busch, right, and his brother Kyle share a moment during pole qualifying for the NASCAR Nextel Cup UAW-DaimlerChrysler 400 at Las Vegas Motor Speedway on Friday, March 9, 2007. The brothers got a little close later that year, wrecking each other during the NEXTEL All-Star Race in Concord, N.C. 
ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISE HERE (Credit: Getty/Jonathan Ferrey) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the #2 Miller Lite Dodge, and Tony Stewart, driver of the #20 The Home Depot Chevrolet, pull into the garage after colliding on track during practice for the Budweiser Shootout at Daytona International Speedway on February 8, 2008 in Daytona, Florida. During a meeting in the NASCAR hauler, Stewart reportedly punched Busch. (Credit: Getty/Rusty Jarrett) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the #2 Miller Lite/Vortex Dodge, celebrates in Victory Lane after winning the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Coca-Cola 600 at Charlotte Motor Speedway on May 30, 2010 in Concord, North Carolina. This win came a week after his victory in the Sprint All-Star Race at the track, earning him a payday in excess of $1 million. (Credit: AP) 
Jimmie Johnson, with cap at left, has an exchange with Kurt Busch, right, in yellow suit, after the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series auto race, Sunday, Aug. 7, 2011, at Pocono Raceway in Long Pond, Pennsylvania. (Credit: AP/Steve Helber) 
Kurt Busch waves to the crowd during driver introductions prior to the start of the NASCAR Sprint Cup race at the Richmond International Raceway in Richmond, Va.. Angry because his car wasn't competitive, Busch railed against his crew during the early portion of the race. He pointedly blamed Penske Racing's shortcomings on technical director Tom German over a radio frequency available to the public. (Credit: Getty/Patrick Smith) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the #22 Shell/Pennzoil Dodge, spins during the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Wonderful Pistachios 400 at Richmond International Raceway on September 10, 2011 in Richmond, Virginia. Busch apologized after arguing with multiple reporters who asked about his rivalry with Jimmie Johnson following the race. 
ADVERTISEMENT ADVERTISE HERE (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 22 Shell/Pennzoil Dodge, in the garage during practice for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Ford 400 at Homestead-Miami Speedway on Nov. 19, 2011, in Homestead, Florida. Busch was released from his contract after the season-ending race after his verbal assault on veteran NASCAR TV personality Dr. Jerry Punch. (Credit: Getty Images) 
After his release from Penske Racing, Kurt Busch spent 2012 participating in the Sprint Cup for the small Phoenix Racing team while also driving a limited schedule for brother Kyle Busch's Nationwide Series team. Here, Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 54 Monster Energy Toyota, left, poses with Kyle after winning the Nationwide Series Virginia 529 College Savings 250 at Richmond International Raceway on April 27, 2012, in Richmond, Virginia. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 51 Phoenix Construction Services Chevrolet, during qualifying for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Aaron's 499 at Talladega Superspeedway on May 5, 2012, in Talladega, Alabama. Busch ran the "ME" paint scheme from the "Talladega Nights" film, a deal largely brokered by then-girlfriend Patricia Driscoll. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 51 Phoenix Construction Services Chevrolet, is held back during a scuffle with Ryan Newman, driver of the No. 39 Wix Filters Chevrolet, during the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Bojangles' Southern 500 at Darlington Raceway on May 12, 2012, in Darlington, South Carolina. Busch was placed on probation for this incident. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kyle Busch talks with younger brother Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 54 Monster Energy Toyota, after the NASCAR Nationwide Series 5-hour Energy 200 at Dover International Speedway on June 2, 2012, in Dover, Delaware. Kurt Busch, on probation from the Darlington incident, made threatening statements toward a reporter after the race and was suspended for the next weekend at Pocono. (Credit: Getty Images) 
In 2013, Kurt Busch moved to Furniture Row Racing. With better financial backing and an alliance with Richard Childress Racing, Busch took advantage. Busch, driver of the No. 78 Furniture Row/Beautyrest Chevrolet, left, and younger brother Kyle Busch, driver of the No. 18 M&M's American Heritage Chocolate Toyota, celebrate after qualifying for the Chase for the Sprint Cup after the Federated Auto Parts 400 at Richmond International Raceway on Sept. 7, 2013, in Richmond, Virginia. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Tony Stewart, driver of the No. 14 Rush Truck Centers/Mobil 1 Chevrolet, and Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 78 Furniture Row Racing/Serta Chevrolet, collide in the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Toyota Owners 400 at Richmond International Raceway on April 27, 2013, in Richmond, Virginia. The pair banged their cars against each other after the race, then got out of their Chevrolets and sparred verbally. (Credit: AP) 
Kurt Busch and Patricia Driscoll at the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series auto racing awards ceremony at The Wynn Resort & Casino in Las Vegas on Dec. 6, 2013. (Credit: AP Photo/Mike McCarn) 
Brad Keselowski (2) bumps Kurt Busch (41) as they enter Turn 1 during a NASCAR Sprint Cup race at Martinsville Speedway on Sunday, March 30, 2014, in Martinsville, Va. The two drivers were involved in a pit road accident earlier in the race. Busch ended up winning the race, securing his spot in the 2014 Chase for the Sprint Cup Championship. Keselowski and Busch traded threats during and after the race. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Gene Haas, co-owner of Stewart-Haas Racing with Tony Stewart, hired Kurt Busch and funded a fourth Stewart-Haas car for him in 2014. Here, Busch, driver of the No. 41 Haas Automation Chevrolet, stands on pit road with then-girlfriend Patricia Driscoll after qualifying for the Chase for the Sprint Cup during the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series Federated Auto Parts 400 at Richmond International Raceway on Sept. 6, 2014, in Richmond, Virginia. (Credit: AP) 
Kurt Busch prepares to kiss girlfriend Patricia Driscoll after dropping out of the NASCAR Sprint Cup series Coca-Cola 600 at Charlotte Motor Speedway in Concord, North Carolina, on May 25, 2014, Busch's second race of the day after completing the Indianapolis 500. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch, driver of the No. 41 Haas Automation Chevrolet, in his car during practice for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series AAA 400 at Dover International Speedway on Sept. 26, 2014, in Dover, Delaware. Busch's former girlfriend, Patricia Driscoll, claims he physically assaulted her in his motor home after a poor qualifying effort that day. (Credit: Getty Images) 
Kurt Busch leaves the IMC building after a suspension appeal hearing on February 21, 2015 in Daytona Beach, Florida. Busch was suspended indefinitely by NASCAR after a no-contact order was issued against him for alleged abuse against his ex-girlfriend Patricia Driscoll. Busch was reinstated by NASCAR on March 11, 2015, with the sanctioning body citing Delaware officials choosing not to file criminal charges against Busch, as well as Busch's compliance with NASCAR's reinstatement program. (Credit: AP) 
Kurt Busch celebrates after winning the NASCAR Sprint Cup auto race at Richmond International Raceway in Richmond, Va., on April 26, 2015. The win qualified Busch for NASCAR's Chase for the Sprint Cup playoffs. (Credit: AP/John Raoux) 
Kurt Busch stands on pit road with his then-girlfriend, Ashley Van Metre, before the NASCAR Sprint Unlimited auto race at Daytona International Speedway, Saturday, Feb. 14, 2015, in Daytona Beach, Fla. The pair married in January 2017. (Credit: AP/Matt Slocum) 
Kurt Busch celebrates with his team in Victory Lane after winning the NASCAR Sprint Cup at Pocono Raceway on June 6, 2016, in Long Pond, Pa. The win punched Busch's ticket for the 2016 Chase playoffs. (Credit: Getty Images / Sean Gardner) 
Kurt Busch celebrates after winning the Daytona 500 on February 26, 2017 in Daytona Beach, Florida. Enter your email address to subscribe to Newsday's Sports Now newsletter
